awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Practical and Robust Hidden Voice Commands
awd_abstract_narration:
Systems like Amazon's Alexa, Google Home and Apple's Siri allow users to issue voice commands and pose questions to personal digital assistants.  Since these systems often have access to sensitive data and can perform tasks with serious impact (e.g., spend money to make a purchase), attacks against them could have significant consequences.  Unfortunately, recent research has shown that attacks against such voice-based interfaces are feasible. This project is exploring methods of securing the voice interfaces to smartphones and other devices to ensure that commands are only accepted from the devices' owners.
 
The researchers recently introduced the notion of hidden voice commands: audio that is constructed to be interpreted as voice commands by a computer speech recognition system, but is incomprehensible to human listeners.  In theory, attackers may use hidden voice commands to surreptitiously control victims' smartphones and other electronic devices.  Is this a realistic threat in practice? This project is studying both the practicality of this threat and approaches to protection.  First, the researchers are investigating whether an attacker could construct hidden voice commands efficiently and covertly and make the commands operate under realistic conditions to circumvent previously proposed defenses.  Second, they are developing scalable detection techniques and defenses that reliably and efficiently prevent such attacks.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to better understand the real-world, practical threats posed by hidden voice commands -- covert communication channels that exploit the differences in how humans and computers interpret speech.  The project is organized into three main research directions: (1) developing more effective hidden voice commands to improve our understanding of the vulnerability of voice interfaces; (2) examining the feasibility of hidden voice channels that are robust against voice systems that employ speaker recognition; and (3) constructing automated defenses to improve the resiliency of voice systems against hidden voice commands.

 

Significant outcomes of this award include:

 

  • Confirmation that inaudible voice commands can be effective against commodity speaker recognition tools:  We demonstrated that inaudible hidden voice commands could be constructed such that (1) voice authentication systems would incorrectly attribute the commands to a particular speaker and (2) the commands could be generated in an automated fashion.

 

  • Construction of effective defenses for traffic analysis attacks against voice-over-IP (VoIP) systems: We explored how the theory of hidden voice commands could be applied to enact defenses against traffic analysis attacks.  We developed a unilateral technique that leverages the theory behind hidden voice commands to construct a transparent security layer around voice-over-IP systems, preventing forms of traffic analysis and information leakage.  Our Whisper defense system appeared in ACSAC 2019.

 

  • Development of new methods for protecting against voice synthesis attacks: We examined techniques for applying the methods used to construct hidden voice commands to defend against voice synthesis attacks, a form of audio deepfake.  We showed that voice recognition and voice accumulation (that is, the accumulation of users? voices) are separable.  In a paper published at IWPE, we introduced techniques for locally sanitizing voice inputs before they are transmitted to the cloud for processing.  Such methods employ audio processing techniques to remove distinctive voice characteristics, leaving only the information that is necessary for the cloud-based services to perform speech recognition.  This effectively prevents state-of-the-art voice synthesis techniques from constructing convincing forgeries of a user?s speech while still permitting accurate voice recognition.

 

  • Reducing privacy leakage in monitored communication: Finally, inspired by our work in developing Whisper, we explored defenses against privacy leakage due to monitored communication.  Significant information can be gleaned from eavesdropping on audio communication, including the identity of the speakers, the language being spoken, and even key phrases.  In addition to Whisper, anonymity networks such as Tor make such adversarial traffic analysis much more difficult due to its use of padding and its obfuscation of the communication endpoints.  While exploring the methods in which Tor could be applied to IoT devices such as the Amazon Echo and Google Home, we identified a startling high rate of blocking of Tor communication, not by network adversaries or censors, but rather by the intended recipients of the anonymous communication.  We developed a suite of countermeasures, appearing in the DSN and CCS conferences, that makes it more difficult to discriminate against traffic arriving from anonymity networks.  Our first approach establishes egress points for anonymity networks in popular cloud providers (AWS), making it difficult to distinguish between traffic that is relayed through the cloud as part of an anonymity network versus traffic belonging to cloud-hosted workstations.  Our second approach provides incentives for ordinary users to act as ephemeral exit points for anonymity networks, in exchange for micropayments.  Both approaches improve the utility of anonymity services such as Tor, which can be leveraged by always-on listening devices (e.g., Amazon Echo) to better conceal communication patterns to potential eavesdroppers.



Intellectual Merits  

Voice input is becoming increasingly ubiquitous as a method of interacting with computing devices. This project concerns a new threat against these interfaces: hidden voice commands that exploit the differences in how humans and computers interpret speech to allow an adversary to inject voice commands that are unlikely to be noticed by a human operator. This project significantly increased our understanding of this threat by exploring methods by which hidden voice commands can be generated as well as efficient and scalable defensive techniques for protecting voice-activated systems. 

 

Broader Impacts

There has been a proliferation of devices that accept voice commands. Increasingly, IoT devices (e.g., smart speakers) and wearables interact with their human operators almost exclusively through voice interfaces. This project?s research activities strengthened the security of these interfaces (and consequently, the devices themselves) by (1) improving our understanding of a new threat?hidden voice commands?and (2) developing robust and scalable defenses.  Results from this work, which include peer-reviewed papers and software (released with open source licenses) are available online at https://seclab.cs.georgetown.edu/publications/.
